ygData.subject: Re: Novelty Search
ygData.msgSnippet: Looks like I missed that part. Sorry about that. If however I understand correctly what you did, it is not exactly a random search. You write that you run NEAT

Looks like I missed that part. Sorry about that. If however I understand co=
rrectly what you did, it is not exactly a random search. You write that you=
 run NEAT with randomly assigned fitness. In such search there should be si=
gnificant correlations between the tested individuals, since despite the ra=
ndom selection, much of the genetic material is inherited from past individ=
uals. This is not at all what we would want in a random search. Additionall=
y you would get genomes becoming larger with time(probably much faster than=
 we would want in a random search).
I would expect these deviations from a =
random search to cause an uneven exploration of the genotype space. Thus th=
e resulting performance should be worse than that of a random search. I don=
't know however if the difference will be significant (It depends on the sp=
ecifics of the evolutionary algorithm).

I agree that it seems that novelty=
 search will spend less time on degenerate behaviors than a random search. =
Any ideas on how to quantify this difference?
